reviewText: This could be called "The Tale of Two Elizabeths", as the film skillfully interwines the stories of young Elizabeth Thatcher and the aunt whose name she carries. Those familiar with Janette Oke's Canadian West series will recognize the story of Elizabeth Thatcher and Wynn Delaney, but this film is the story of Elizabeth's namesake who is deciding if she is brave enough to head west for her first teaching assignment. Aunt Elizabeth's story is shown through flashback's as her neice reads through the diary her sister "borrowed" from their parent's safe.With her courage gathered, and believing this is what God has called her to do, Elizabeth decides to head west and share her love of learning with the children in a small coal mining town. Against her wishes, her father requests family friend, Edward Montclair of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, to see that she safely arrives at her destination. Her disdain turns to admiration as they journey across the land.The dvd leaves you wanting more of this story. Fortunately for those who receive the Hallmark Channel, the story does continue as a television series scheduled to begin January 4th. (I did notice that there will be different actors in some of the major roles, but am pleased to see Lori Loughlin in both the film and the series. I also loved seeing Jean Smart in the film!) However, just because this movie is a pilot, it does not mean it is not a satisfying stand-alone film. I thoroughly enjoyed watching the movie and was content with the way it ended. Of course, I want to know more, but I felt that the ending was one that left a feeling of hope and a promise of good things to come. The scenery was gorgeous, and the story was a well told blend of romance, comedy, tragedy, and a touch of history. I have seen and enjoyed several of Michael Landon Jr.'s films, but I do believe that this is my favorite of all.Disclosure: I received this dvd compliments of Word Films and Edify Media for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

reviewText: Gathering dust in some vault of the bizarre may be a photo of Jeannete Oke and Debbie MaComber together in a tattoo parlor, getting tatted up. It's perhaps right next to photos of Norman Rockwell kicking a dog and Bill Cosby rejecting a Pudding Pop. Anyway, I'm not sure that Jeanette Oke - with her debut novel Love Comes Softly (1979) - didn't end up inventing the historical Christian romance. Or if not invent it, then popularize it. I'm a stranger in these here parts. For me, the historical Christian romance is mostly uncharted territory. But I'd seen (if not read) several chapters in Jeanette Oke's Love Comes Softly television saga. And I'm eager to branch out and sample the author's other wares. When Calls the Heart is Mrs. Oke's launch of her Canadian West series. After having seen it adapted to the small screen, I'm so glad to learn that there'll be an ongoing television series premiering in 2014 (January 4th, if precision's your bag).When Maggie Grace isn't being abducted by Albanians and when Stephen Amell isn't accusing crooks of failing his city, they hang out together on the Canadian prairie frontier. When Calls the Heart unveils two parallel storylines, and Grace and Amell are the co-leads in one of them. It's looking like the ongoing series will be tracking the other, more modern story arc. I doubt very much that Maggie Grace and Stephen Amell can commit to a season's worth of episodes.Pampered 22-year-old Elizabeth Thatcher (Poppy Drayton) wants so badly to be a teacher. She dreams of inspiring young students. But Elizabeth leads a sheltered city life. When she's assigned a teaching post in the distant Canadian frontier town of Coal Valley (just west of the Rockies), she isn't certain she can cut the rugged life. She turns to her aunt's diary for comfort and guidance.Turns out, her long-not-heard-from aunt (Maggie Grace) - whose name is also Elizabeth - had blazed the trail for her many years ago. Aunt Elizabeth was a teacher, too, and cultured and refined and most inexperienced in facing the hardships of the frontier. Luckily - and, no, this doesn't at all stretch coincidence to the snapping point - both women, in their own time, become acquainted with their respective Mounties (Stephen Amell, Daniel Sharman).Maggie Grace and Poppy Drayton share enough of a resemblance that I easily bought into their being kinfolk. Both actresses do well in retaining the viewer's interest; both are very personable and sympathetic (and, speaking as a guy, no demerits for their looking so stunning). I was instantly absorbed with their respective arcs and the conflicts that challenged them, whether it's Maggie Grace's Elizabeth striving to put her stamp on her new community or Poppy Drayton's "modern-day" Elizabeth trying to gather resolve enough to brave the unknown. I appreciate the authentic period flavor (but did they really say "Okay" back then?). Bits of levity are peppered in to undercut the dramatic tension as this or that Elizabeth experiences comic misadventures concerning rampaging mice and mysterious cabin stoves. The moment that tickled me most is Drayton's throwaway remark as she tries to figure out the workings of a mouse trap ("I purchased several of these killing devices...").Past time the Hallmark Channel started producing its own television shows. We could all use more original family programming. Cedar Cove was a fine start, but I'm more stoked about the upcoming When Calls the Heart series. In the final minutes of this movie, we learn the dire obstacles that face Elizabeth in desolate Coal Valley, and that just whets my appetite. And, in a bit of a segue, I admit to also very much looking forward to the upcoming Signed, Sealed, Delivered series and also The Weepy Wastrels of the West. I may have made up one of those last two.

reviewText: This movie When Calls the Heart is about a young woman named Elizabeth Thatcher (Poppy Drayton) who decided to become a teacher. Elizabeth's family is wealthy for people who live in 1910.  At first Elizabeth gets a assigned to be a teacher in the prairie. Elizabeth's family does not think Elizabeth can handle living in the prairie after living with servants all her life.  Elizabeth finds her aunt Elizabeth's secret diary and learns some things about the aunt she never knew. Elizabeth's parents are worried for Elizabeth to take the teaching job in the prairie because things did not go well for Aunt Elizabeth (Maggie Grace) in the prairie. Elizabeth goes to live in the little house near her family house to prove to them she can live by herself. Watch this movie to see if Elizabeth ever proves to her family she can live by herself or not. Find out if Elizabeth goes to the prairie to teach like her aunt or does she stays closer to home? Enjoy!!!

reviewerName: Laura of Harvest Lane Cottage "Laura of Harve...
reviewText: When Calls the Heart has just been released.  I had the privilege of receiving a free copy for review.  It's a movie based on the book of the same name by Janette Oke.  I first read my first Oke book back when my oldest son was a preschooler.  She's had several of her books made into movies.  You might recognize the Love Comes Softly series.We enjoyed this movie very much.  The scenery, the costuming, the details were wonderfully rich.  The acting was superb.  The music was appropriate and good.  We liked everything about this movie from beginning to end.  Except. One. Thing.  I forgot that this book was the first in a series.  Therefore, when we got to the very end, it ended.  Abruptly.  Without Closure.  Ugh!  My kids complained.Will we watch the television series when it comes out?  No, at least not unless it comes out on video someday.  We don't have television access.  We just watch selected movies.Would I still recommend the movie?  Yes, it's really good.  I loved the interplay of the characters.  Two story lines are being told at the same time.

reviewText: The start of the next Janette Oke series to film directed by Michael Landon Jr. offers another clean, Dove approved, Harkmark film.Taking place near the turn of the 19th/20th Century with two stories about pioneer life. One features Maggie Grace(Californication) as the aunt who first courts isolation on the prarie and struggles with teaching.  Her tale is discovered by her niece(played petulantly well by Poppy Drayton) who reads her aunt's diary, and will eventually, follow in her footsteps.The niece lives in high, spoiled society with loving parents(including the talented veteran, Cherie Lunghi), and battles with her sister over everything.It's a flashback of similar but different adventures, the women are beseiged with ineptitude and helped by handsome, knowing men/romantic interests.The actors are gorgeous. The story's a bit corny and slow in parts but easily overlooked, especially, if you like the other Ms. Oke's novels and movies.  The outdoor shots are beautiful, and I found the second half much more interesting and better paced when the niece finally heads west *SPOILER ALERT* with, of course, handsome, male Mountie along for protection and romantic conflict.*END ALERT*A very clean movie with some threatening situations, and, in general, ok for the kids if they'll sit for it. The ending leaves you hanging wanting more, aka, the sequel, probably the start of many.Overall: lightweight, predictable, romantic dramedy with nice period setting on par with other Michael Landon Jr. movies.

reviewText: I liked everything about this movie except the ending. Left me hanging.  but in 2014 this movie will be a series, I will definitely watch it, and hope they start the series where the movie left off.This is a movie you can watch as a family. The story takes place the turn of the nineteenth/twentieth century.  It is about a young lady named Elizabeth Thatcher that is a teacher  Her family want her to stay close to home to teach and not leave.  Her mother went so far as to bribe Mr. Higgins to give young Elizabeth a position close to home, and when Elizabeth finds this out she is even more determined to prove to herself and her family she can do it in Coral Valley.Young  Elizabeth stumbles across her Aunt Elizabeth's diary in the family safe.  She starts to read it, and finds that her aunt was also a teacher.  She wants to follow in her aunt's footsteps. Young Elizabeth decides to the teaching position in Coral Valley, despite her sister pleading with her not to go.To young Elizabeth's surprise as she is on the train to coral Valley, her father has sent family friend, Edward Montclair of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police to be sure Elizabeth gets to Coral Valley safely. As the two travel Elizabeth's destination, they encounter a bit of danger and Elizabeth is ready to give up, but Edward won't allow that to happen.  Miss Elizabeth Thatcher arrives to Coral Valley.  And it will be quite a challenge for her, one she is willing to accept.Reviewed by Elisa for New Age Mama

reviewText: At the turn of the century aspiring teacher Elizabeth Thatcher is anxiously seeking a position which will prove to her family she can indeed take care of herself.A Society girl, she dreads leaving the comforts of home but when the opportunity to teach in Coal City comes up, she embraces the challenge.An old diary written by her father's younger sister and her namesake fuels Elizabeth's imagination and she is determined to discover a whole new life out west for herself.Fearing for their daughter, her parents seek the help of a family friend, now a Mountie, to chaperon her whilst she travels to her destination.What happens then is just the sort of adventure Elizabeth is seeking and the realization of what it entails, exceeds her wildest dreams!Based on the novel written by Janette Oke, When Calls The Heart reflects the family entertainment we have learned to expect from Director Michael Landon Jr.With stunning scenery and even more beautifully detailed costumes, this sweet story gives you the opportunity to treat your loved ones to a great Christian movie with a wonderful message!5 Stars!I received a copy of this DVD title from Edify Media Inc/Word Entertainment to review . I am disclosing this in accordance with the FTC 16 CFR, Part 255 'Guides concerning the use of endorsements and testimonials in advertising. I was not asked to write a positive review and all opinions expressed are entirely my own.
summary: Stunning scenery and even more beautifully detailed costumes!

reviewText: What happens when you blend together two very different periods in time into a poignant movie? For me, you get a sensational movie to speaks to both your heart and soul! Think Dowtown Abbey meets the old west and you have the backdrop to When Calls The Heart, a family movie from Michael Landon Jr and Word Films.This is the film adaptation of the story by best selling author Janette Oke about Elizabeth Thatcher who wishes to make a difference in her life by using her teaching skills to work in a school. But soon after meeting with Mr. Higgins, she learns the only way she'll be able to get a teaching position is if she is willing to do whatever it takes to show Mr. Higgins just how grateful she truly is. However Mr. Higgins isn't suggesting the same type of gratefulness that Elizabeth is. She is horrified to learn that when she declines his proposition, the only available teaching position he offers her, is one out west in Coal Valley that he believes she will never take. Being the daughter of a prominent high society family, she feels confident she should prove them all wrong, even her parents who believe that the horrors of living on the west will be more than she can handle.Her sister Julie, even goes so far to prove her point by suggesting she live in the old caretakers cottage on the family estate without aid of servants to cook and clean for her. She doesn't expect Elizabeth to take the wager and believes her strong determination to prove her family wrong will ultimately win. But Julie isn't about to be swayed. She takes it upon herself to make sure that Elizabeth is an uncomfortable in the cottage as possible even using some hints from an old family diary she discovers locked in her parents safe to help speed along the wager.However armed with the determination of not only in proving her family and Mr. Higgins wrong, Elizabeth immerses herself in the diary of her Aunt Elizabeth who left the family to head west for a teaching position herself in Pine Springs and chronicles just how difficult it was but how perseverance and faith in God allowed her to triumph where others believe she would fail. The movie toggles between the story of both Elizabeth's living in different time periods but with similar circumstances that cheer one another to move forward in their quest to do what each of them believes is a calling in their own heart to make a difference.I received When Calls the Heart compliments of Word Films and Edify Media for my honest review and did not receive any monetary compensation for a favorable one. My only wish is for more of this series. My youngest daughter when we viewed the trailer couldn't wait for the movie to come in the mail to review. She was anticipating this one as much as I was. We were not disappointed when we literally watched it the same day we got it. She even cried during the movie but it goes to show just how much storms will try our character and faith but in the long run, it truly is worth the effort. Hands down, a perfect 5 out of 5 star rating in our opinion and one we have added to our own personal family library collection. This is a film for all ages to view and LOVE that more films like this are being masterfully created for us to enjoy at home. This movie aired previously on the Hallmark Channel and had led to the creation of a television series coming in 2014.
summary: Loved this movie! Can't wait for more!!!

reviewText: Some of my most favorite childhood memories are of winter nights when my family read books aloud together. There was everything from C.S. Lewis to Janette Oke. It's no surprise that when the Hallmark Channel undertook some of Janette's most beloved novels, I was first in line to see them. Now following the somewhat disappointing Love Comes Softly series, they've tackled her Canadian West novels...Young Beth Thatcher (Poppy Drayton) has only ever wanted one thing; to make a difference by becoming a teacher. After earning her teaching certificate, Beth's cultured upbringing assumes she'll get a post not far from her home in the east only to instead be given a posting in the rugged mining town of Coal Valley. When indecision over the post plagues her along with her sister's taunting she wouldn't survive she finds her Aunt Elizabeth's journal, and life suddenly changes. Reading about the life of Elizabeth (Maggie Grace), Beth slowly begins to learn more about the aunt she never knew...Leaving her Eastern life to become a teacher in the unforgiving frontier, Elizabeth Thatcher faces the harsh realities of adjusting to a new place without the amenities of home, but with love for her students and all the joy they bring to her life, Elizabeth adjusts. Then she meets Wynn Delaney (Stephan Amell), a handsome Mountie whose courage and kind attention to Elizabeth slowly makes her rethink what she thought she always wanted.Much like Janette's popular Love Comes Softly series, this foursome of novels was once a favorite. I like that it was so different than the `Love' saga and if memory serves correctly I was always fond of Elizabeth. Of course, the leading man being in uniform had nothing to do with my attraction either - after all, it's not like I have a thing for noble guys who "serve and protect" or anything like that. Really, I don't. Learning who had been cast in this telefilm was also another form of temptation since I've seen Amell and Grace in prior roles that I'd respected; now they brought to life the charming characters of Wynn and Elizabeth Delaney splendidly (needless to say, I'll avoid gushing) along with the rest of the cast which includes newcomer Drayton (who was an easily lovable heroine) Cheri Lunghi and briefly, Lori Loughlin.The closer the release of this 2-hour film came, the more conflicting news was released about it. If you're confused by their being not one but two "Elizabeth Thatcher's" in the story, never fear, you aren't seeing double. Here are some of the facts about this Michael Landon Jr. script. Instead of being a one-time telefilm, this was actually the launch (a pilot film) for an upcoming original series on Hallmark Channel. Set to premiere in 2014, the series named When Calls the Heart is not only going to recast its primary cast, its main story line will be chronicling Elizabeth Thatcher's name sake; here Elizabeth and Wynn's story is told through flashbacks and Beth is the girl we follow journeying to her new life. To confess, I thought said evocations were sweet and timed nicely however as a girl who was expecting to watch Elizabeth and Wynn's story come to life, a part of me was disappointed. That being said, perhaps this is better since now I won't be able to count on the series following beloved novels (just the same, I expect some things will be dealt with as a kind of "throwback" to the novels) religiously and also admiration is part of my conclusion since it'll be fun to watch a new saga unfold - one we won't be able to predict by flipping through the pages of a novel.What is charismatic about this script was the unexpected bouts of humor - it adds some sass and permits more personality. Then there is the "missing" element - the romance. Sure, there are some pair offs however because of limited screen time, we never feel swept away by the love story. Beth I can forgive because unless I miss my guess she'll be dealing with plenty of romantic angst, however assuming that the Delaney's story is over, it'd have been nice to be gifted a "better" picture of their story rather than focusing on Beth. The pretty costumes make up for any minor quibbles though some of the details are "too big" or "gaudy" for the otherwise pretty dresses. Adding atmosphere are the shots of countryside and the script isn't half bad. If you like sweet prairie romance or fiction, this movie is for you. The ending is surprisingly ambiguous however given this being the origins of a series, I totally understand that and considering that frame, it's almost necessary to leave viewer's wanting so much more.Copyright  2013 * Dreaming Under the Same Moon
summary: Sweet Pilot for a Hallmark Original Series

reviewText: Let me say it was well photographed, the actors were superior.  I had read the book and expected to see the movie that Stephen Amell made of the story.  Instead I only got a few pieces of that movie and that story and the rest was the current story being passed off as When Calls the Heart.  Although it was a good story, it was sold under false pretense,  I did not get the first movie, which it looked like.  I had been searching for several years for that movie.  I depended on Hallmark's reputation and got instead a bait and switch.  And if that wasn't bad enough, the story it told of the new young  RCMP  and the young girl was incomplete.  I feel like I was cheated - out of both stories.  This was misleading and bordering on an out and out lie.

reviewText: I’ve read all of Janette Oke’s Canadian West series which starts with the book When Calls the Heart. I really loved this series and while this DVD When Calls the Heart is a lot alike the book it is different also. I wish the DVD was more like the book. In the book it just tells the story of Elizabeth and Wynn but the DVD tells of two separate stories. The Elizabeth of the book is the Aunt in this DVD while another Elizabeth is the niece. They both are from privileged families and both want to be school teachers, both ends up teaching in the Wild West. Another thing both start to like Canadian Mounties.  It’s like a story told twice in this movie.I do love the characters and the acting is tremendously good. The settings and scenery are excellent. This could be a 5-star DVD if it only had one story line.Even though I don’t like the two story lines I still think this is an excellent DVD to buy and watch. Great love story.“Disclosure of Material Connection: I received one of the products  mentioned above for free in the hope that I would mention it on my blog. Regardless, I only recommend products or services I use personally and believe will be good for my readers. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission’s 16 CFR, Part 255: “Guides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.”
summary: Nice DVD but different from the book.
